titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Asia Programs, Regional Director, Office Files of Peter F. Geithner
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Asia Programs, Regional Director, Office Files of Peter F. Geithner FA1532

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-04-01 09:45:51 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Asia Programs, Regional Director, Office Files of Peter F. Geithner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the office files Peter F. Geithner created and managed during his career at the Ford Foundation. The collection is arranged into record groups. Each record group corresponds to a different position Geithner held at the Foundation. Throughout his time at the Foundation, Geithner's work primarily concentrated on program activity in Asia, and his last position at the Foundation before his retirement was Regional Director of Asia Programs.
To date, the collection contains two record groups:
Record Group 1 documents Geithner's position as Program Officer in Charge of the Developing Countries Program from 1981 to 1987.
Record Group 2 documents Geithner's position as Regional Director of Asia Programs from 1990 to 1996.

Records in the collection document the Ford Foundation's similar programming for China and Vietnam during periods of economic change and improved diplomatic relations with the United States. These time periods were the 1980s for China and the 1990s for Vietnam. Ford worked with agencies and government groups in the countries as well as with other foundations and research centers to support economic development and training, legal education, and improved international relations for China and Vietnam. This work which Geithner helped lead preceded the Foundation opening its field offices in Beijing, China in 1988 and Hanoi, Vietnam in 1996.

Files in the collection also show the Foundation's support for integrating sustainable resource management with economic and agricultural development in various Asian countries like Vietnam and Bangladesh through activities like social forestry.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of two records groups and six series.
Original order was maintained as much as possible.
The collection arrangement is as follows:
Record Group 1. Developing Countries Program Office Files, 1970-1988
RG1 Series 1. Meeting and trip files, 1970-1987
RG1 Series 2. Subject files, 1973-1988
RG1 Series 2. Subject files. Subseries 1. China, 1979-1988
RG1 Series 2. Subject files. Subseries 2. General, 1973-1985
RG1 Series 3. Chronology files, 1981-1986
Record Group 2. Asia Programs Office Files, 1975-1996
RG2 Series 1. Conferences, 1991-1992
RG2 Series 2. Correspondence, 1989-1995
RG2 Series 3. Subject files, 1975-1996
RG2 Series 3. Subject files. Subseries 1. Vietnam, 1988-1995
RG2 Series 3. Subject files Subseries 2. General, 1975-1995
RG2 Series 3. Subject files Subseries 3. Bangladesh, 1991-1996

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.
This material was transferred to the RAC in various accessions between 2011 and 2023 and was ingested by the RAC as Accessions 2011:072, 2012:025, 2019:050, 2019:136, 2021:110, and 2023:017.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Asia Programs office originated in 1958 as a division of the Overseas Development program then called the Overseas Development/South and Southeast Asia. In 1966, South and Southeast Asia office shifted to the International Division program area as part of a Foundation reorganization and, in 1968, the office was renamed Asia and the Pacific. In 1981, the office became part of the Developing Countries Program. The Asia Programs became a full program area in 1989.

At various points throughout its history, the Asia Programs maintained field offices in: New Delhi, India; Jakarta, Indonesia; Dhaka, Bangladesh; Bangkok, Thailand; Manila, Philippines; and Hanoi, Vietnam.

did.unittitle: Record Group 1 Developing Countries Program Office Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Record Group 1 is comprised of three series.
RG1 Series 1. Meeting and trip files, 1970-1987
RG1 Series 2. Subject files, 1973-1988
RG1 Series 2. Subject files. Subseries 1. China, 1979-1988
RG1 Series 2. Subject files. Subseries 2. General, 1973-1985
RG1 Series 3. Chronology files, 1981-1986

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains the office files Peter F. Geithner created during his time as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program (DCP). Materials span from Geithner's entire 1981 to 1987 tenure as DCP Program Officer in Charge. The collection is comprised of meeting and trip files, subject files, and chronology files.

Meeting files document the work that Geithner, other Ford Foundation staff members such as the different Field Officer Representatives, and external individuals and organizations completed for organizing, participating in, and reporting on various Ford Foundation program meetings and other types of events and conferences. Trip files document Geithner's visits to various countries and Ford Foundation field offices as well as the visits he helped organize for individuals like Foundation Board of Trustees Members.

Subject files largely concern the Foundation's programming regarding China. There are also some more general DCP administrative and program subject files. The chronology files contain copies of correspondence Geithner sent throughout his time as DCP Program Officer in Charge.

Geithner's files provide insight into the Developing Countries Program's interest in and support of initiatives concerning economic development, agricultural development, child survival, and reproductive health in countries throughout Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East during the 1980s. They also document the Foundation's growing program activity related to China ahead of its opening its Beijing, China field office in 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains the meeting and trip files that Peter F. Geithner created during his time as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program (DCP). Meeting files generally concern the review of the Foundation's actions regarding issues such as employment and income generation, child survival, and reproductive health in developing countries throughout Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East as well as the planning and organization of additional actions to support the study and tackling of these issues. The series also includes meeting files that document other types of events such as a meeting the Ford Foundation organized between different foundations and Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India, to discuss economic development and grant clearance procedures in India. Trip files concern the different visits Geithner organized for himself and other individuals like members of the Ford Foundation Board of Trustees to various countries and Foundation field offices. Some of the travel advisory memos within the trip files provide insight into the political situations and trends of these countries such as the opposition to President Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines and the violence of Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) in Peru.

Although most of the series' files were created during Geithner's tenure as Program Officer in Charge of the DCP, there does appear to be some material that was created just before Geithner moved from his previous position as Representative for Southeast Asia in the Bangkok, Thailand Regional Office.

did.physdesc: File contains a set of still images.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains a group of photographs taken during Ford Foundation Board of Trustees' Member Rodrigo Botero's visit to countries in East and Southeast Asia in 1985. Individuals captured in the photographs include Botero, his wife Louise, and Han Sung-joo, Director of the Asiatic Research Center and professor of international relations at Korea University and the Boteros' host in Korea. Photographs were originally contained in a small album from Bangkok, Thailand.

did.unittitle: North Africa and Middle East trips
New York City, New York trip
Tom Wyman, Ford Foundation Trustee - India trip

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the subject files Peter F. Geithner created when he served as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program between 1981 and 1987. It is comprised of two subseries. The first subseries contains records specifically concerning the Foundation's programming for China, and the second subseries contains records documenting more general DCP administration and program activities.

The bulk of the series is contained within the China subseries. During the 1980s, the Ford Foundation expanded its programming for China when diplomatic relations between China and the United States improved. The Foundation would later open its Beijing, China field office in 1988, and Geithner would serve as the Foundation's first China Representative. One file of Geithner's correspondence from that position is included at the end of the first subseries.
In addition to correspondence, the series contains memos, reports, notes, drafts, news clippings, and meeting materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The China subject files subseries documents the work led by Developing Countries Program Officer in Charge Peter F. Geithner regarding the Ford Foundation's programming for China in the 1980s. Materials show the Ford Foundation's communication and collaboration with organizations like the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS) during a time when China underwent economic and political changes and shifting international relations. Foundation programming largely centered on education and research with specific focuses on economics education and training in China, educational exchanges between China and the U.S., law education, Chinese international relations, and research on the changes occurring in China.

The work of groups like the United States Committee on Economics Education and Research in China (CEERC) and the U.S. Committee on Legal Education Exchange with China (CLEEC) are documented in the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The general subject files subseries documents miscellaneous administrative and program activities of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program in the 1980s when Peter F. Geithner was Program Officer in Charge. One of the primary areas of administrative concern centered around DCP policy and organization changes during a time of Ford Foundation Program Division reorganization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the chronology files Peter F. Geithner created and maintained during his tenure as Program Officer in Charge of the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program between 1981 and 1987. Files in the series span from 1981 to 1986.

Each chronology file in the series contains copies of the messages Geithner's office sent during a specific block of time. Within those blocks of time, the correspondence is arranged alphabetically, usually by the person to whom the correspondence is addressed but sometimes by the subject of the correspondence.
The chronology files contain Geithner's internal Ford Foundation communications as well as his messages to external individuals. Within the Foundation, Geithner frequently wrote to:
William Carmichael – Developing Countries Program Vice President
Franklin Thomas – Ford Foundation President
Enid C.B. Schoettle – International Affairs Program (IAP) Program Officer in Charge

Field Office Representatives as a group and several individually such as Lincoln Chen (New Delhi, India), Adrienne Germain (Dhaka, Bangladesh (Dacca)), Thomas Kessinger (Jakarta, Indonesia), Goran Hyden (Nairobi, Kenya), and John Gerhart (Cairo, Egypt)
Joan Carroll – Office of Personnel Services

External individuals include representatives from various foundations, research centers, universities, and governments. Numerous messages to representative of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS) show the Ford Foundation's increasing program interest regarding China.

The correspondence documents various DCP administrative and program activities like trips and visits, program reviews, program budgets, policies, hiring, requests for Ford Foundation support, and grants.

did.unittitle: Record Group 2 Asia Programs Office Files

arrangement.p: Record Group 2 is comprised of three series.
RG2 Series 1. Conferences, 1991-1992
RG2 Series 2. Correspondence, 1989-1995

RG2 Series 3. Subject files. Subseries 2. General, 1975-1995
RG2 Series 3. Subject files. Subseries 3. Bangladesh, 1991-1996

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The second record group in the collection contains the office files Peter F. Geithner created when he served as Regional Director of the Ford Foundation's Asia programs. Materials span across Geithner's entire 1990 to 1996 career as Asia Programs' Regional Director. The record group is comprised of conference files, correspondence, and subject files.

A significant portion of the record group's contents concern the Ford Foundation's programming for Vietnam and Southeast Asia during the 1990s. All of the conference and correspondence files pertain to Vietnam as does a section of the subject files. Within the Asia Programs, programming for Vietnam was largely carried out by the Southeast Asia Program based in the Foundation's Jakarta, Indonesia Office under Representatives David Winder and Mary Zurbuchen and the Bangkok, Thailand Office under Program Officer for Vietnam, Mark Sidel.

Other subject files in the record group show the Asia Programs' broader administrative and program activities. There is also a specific set of subject files concerning programming for Bangladesh and the Ford Foundation's Dhaka Field Office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains conference files Peter F. Geithner created when he served as the Ford Foundation's Regional Director of Asia Programs. The conferences documented in the series concerned Vietnam and Southeast Asia, reflecting the Foundation's program interest in the region during the 1990s.

The files contain typical material formats for preparing for and participating in meetings such as correspondence, notes, agendas, background readings, reports, and a speech. Materials in the series originate from the beginning of Geithner's role as Asia Programs Regional Director in the early 1990s.

did.unittitle: Vietnam - Conference on the Challenges of Vietnam's Reconstruction: Domestic and International Issues, Arlington, Virginia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the correspondence files Peter Geithner created and maintained when he served as Regional Director of Asia Programs at the Ford Foundation. The files are arranged by the subject of the correspondence, and they include correspondence both sent and received by Geithner as well as the correspondence of other Ford Foundation staff which related to Geithner's work as Asia Programs Regional Director. The files in the series all concern the Foundation's work related to Vietnam and Southeast Asia in the first half of the 1990s.

The correspondence in the series is with other Ford Foundation staff, external foundations, Vietnamese agencies, and research centers. It shows the Foundation's interests in supporting economic development and training, rural and agricultural development, legal education, educational exchanges, and improvement of Vietnam-United States relations. The Foundation worked closely with the Vietnamese government for permission of its activities in the country and for its grant recipients traveling in and out of Vietnam.

The files show how much of the Foundation's Vietnam programming largely came out of its Bangkok, Thailand office. Foundation Representatives for Southeast Asia (based out of the Jakarta, Indonesia office) David Winder and Mary Zurbuchen (who succeeded Winder) and Program Officer for Vietnam Mark Sidel contributed significantly to the correspondence in the series. In addition to correspondence, the files also contain notes, drafts, reports, and news clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the subject files Peter F. Geithner created and maintained when he served as Regional Director of the Ford Foundation's Asia Programs between 1990 and 1996. This series is comprised of three subseries. Two of the subseries document Ford Foundation program activities for specific countries with Subseries 1 containing files pertaining to Vietnam and Subseries 3 containing files pertaining to Bangladesh. Subject files in the second subseries are more general and document the broader program and administrative activities of the Asia Programs under Geithner's leadership.

Common material formats found within the series include correspondence, meeting materials, notes, drafts, reports, proposals, newspaper clippings, and Ford Foundation Recommended Grant Action records (RGAs). There are also a few photographs and a file full of bibliographic research notecards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files in this subseries specifically relate to the Ford Foundation's programming for Vietnam and other Southeast Asian countries like Cambodia and Laos during the first half of the 1990s when Peter Geithner was Regional Director of Asia Programs.

Files document the Ford Foundation's collaboration and communication with other foundations working in Vietnam like the Sasakawa Peace Foundation (SPF) and the Social Science Research Council (SSRC). Records highlight the Foundation's specific interests in supporting Vietnam during its time of change including economic development, agricultural development and upland management, reproductive health, and international relations. There are also a few files documenting visits to Vietnam by Ford Foundation staff and Trustees and other organizations.
Ford Foundation Representative for Southeast Asia Mary Zurbuchen and Program Officer for Vietnam Mark Sidel contributed significantly to the materials in the subseries.

United States NGO Forums on Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos
Vietnam Union of Science and Technology Associations (VUSTA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files in this subseries primarily document the strategy, administrative, and program activities of the Ford Foundation's Asia Programs under Peter Geithner's leadership from 1990 to 1996.

Materials in the subseries indicate that reproductive health and sustainable resource management were major areas of focus for the Foundation's Asia Programs during this time. There is a file devoted to a 1993 review of social forestry programming in Asia which includes a photograph from one of the workshops.

More specific activities documented within the subseries include the Foundation delivering severance and final salary payments between 1994 and 1995 to local Vietnamese staff of their former Saigon, Vietnam field office which was shut in 1975 ahead of the Fall of Saigon. A photograph of Geithner meeting with the former staff members and the spouses of former staff members in 1994 is included in the subseries.

There is also a set of bibliographic notecards for research on Asia. The notecards are alphabetically arranged by subject and then author. They include the author, title, and date information of the resources.

did.unittitle: Payments to former local staff - Saigon, Vietnam Field Office

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains 3 copies of the same still image. The photograph shows Peter Geithner meeting with former local Vietnamese staff members of the Ford Foundation's Saigon, Vietnam Field Office as well as spouses of former staff. The photograph is dated March 30, 1994 and was taken at the Ho Chi Minh City External Relations Office. A caption is included on the back of one of the copies. It describes who is who in the photograph. Correspondence in the file shows that Geithner sent a copy of this photograph to everyone depicted within it.

did.langmaterial: File contains documents in Vietnamese and English.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: File contains a still image of participants of Community Forestry in Asia, February 1993. The photograph was taken at the Lake Palace Hotel in Udaipur, India. A caption on the back of the photo describes who is who. Peter Geithner is one of the people captured in the photograph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This report is available in the Ford Foundation Catalogued Reports collection as Catalogued Report 007016 and can be accessed on the RAC Virtual Vault.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files in this subseries provide small insight into the operations of the Ford Foundation's Dhaka, Bangladesh Field Office in the 1990s. The subseries primarily consists of correspondence, Dhaka Office policy materials, papers, and trip reports.

Some of the correspondence in the subseries discusses plans for the closure of the Ford Foundation's Dhaka Office in 1997 and the political situation in the country during the mid-1990s. Geithner's trips to Bangladesh in 1992 and 1994 are documented within the subseries.
Raymond Offenheiser served as Representative for Bangladesh during this time, and his correspondence appears frequently within the subseries.
